body: Also, it would help if you reported your version. I am running the latest master as of a 5 days ago, so I have a pretty fresh copy.

FYI, we (Agari) use the local executor instead of the celery executor. We moved from 1.5.1 to 1.6.1+ (HEAD master) and did not notice any issues with scheduling and our pool. We did not need to recreate any pools, so this sounds like a celery specify problem. It would be good if you changed the title of this issue to reflect that. We run airflow in both staging and prod, so we did the upgrade (via `git pull`, `python setup.py install`, and `airflow upgradedb`) to both without any issues.
There is already a `help-wanted` tag posted on #721
That's interesting: why would it matter if the DAG filename is changed? Shouldn't airflow only care about the ID?
Welcome on board!
@mistercrunch any update? This has been pending for 11 days.

@bolkedebruin OK. I'm planning to write tests too. Then where should I put them? It seems there are no test directories for contrib packages.

Re renaming:  I see. I'll change the name.

Not sure, but did it resolve your issue?

```
                      Table "public.dag"
       Column       |            Type             | Modifiers 
--------------------+-----------------------------+-----------
 dag_id             | character varying(250)      | not null
 is_paused          | boolean                     | 
 is_subdag          | boolean                     | 
 is_active          | boolean                     | 
 last_scheduler_run | timestamp without time zone | 
 last_pickled       | timestamp without time zone | 
 last_expired       | timestamp without time zone | 
 scheduler_lock     | boolean                     | 
 pickle_id          | integer                     | 
 fileloc            | character varying(2000)     | 
 owners             | character varying(2000)     | 
Indexes:
    "dag_pkey" PRIMARY KEY, btree (dag_id)

```

I do see the fileloc set in the dag table. You can try changing the file name, restart the webserver and scheduler, and query the airflow db's `dag` table to see if fileloc column is updated.
@lukun2010 Thank you for solution. Works for me (rhel and mac).
Good to hear, welcome on board!

Not really:

> StatementError: (sqlalchemy.exc.InvalidRequestError) Can't reconnect until invalid transaction is rolled back

but thanks for your help, appreciate it.
@lukun2010 Thanks for your help. Worked for me.
Good to have you on board!

The search scope actually just needs to be changed to SUBTREE instead of LEVEL -- and it's not really AD that's the issue, it's that you're not specifying an OU to match against, and therefore the search_scope must be different.

However this is probably more than just removing some code.

In my opinion, there should probably be a setting in airflow.cfg to set the search scope.

Agreed. I'm using FreeIPA that uses a flat structure so no OUs. You can of course set the ou to match against by setting user_filter. SUBTREE can have performance implications if you don't need it. 

Sent from my iPhone

> On 29 dec. 2015, at 20:52, Neil Hanlon notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> The search scope actually just needs to be changed to SUBTREE instead of LEVEL -- and it's not really AD that's the issue, it's that you're not specifying an OU to match against, and therefore the search_scope must be different.
> 
> However this is probably more than just removing some code.
> 
> In my opinion, there should probably be a setting in airflow.cfg to set the search scope.
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

Yeah... In /most/ setups (even with OUs), this shouldn't be an issue, since in most scenarios the users you'd be trying to grant access would be in the same OU (delegated OU, or something), or at the very least, inside a base OU. However in cases like mine, someone who didn't properly know how to design an AD structure for users designed it, so our users are all over the place, with group membership being the deciding factor for most things.

For very large orgs, subtree will probably kill the box it's running on. I've maxed out CPU on a 12 core Xeon trying to parse a subtree on a huge directory.
out of the box i'm having the same problem
What does your configuration look like?
what do you think now ?
I don't think the CI fail is from me... it looks like the credentials are bad for LDAP in the test?
Either you forked a bad head and need to rebase or your changes broke that test.

This looks sound. `force=True` was definitely a hack and after review of all the code paths I could think of it looks like this should work. 

Unfortunately it'd be hard to write unit test to fully test the pool/prioritize feature though it might be worth it  taking at this point. 

I'm comfortable merging this as is.
Oh and thanks for the PR!

To stick with the common Airflow approach, you'd need a `QuboleHook` to support your operator. Many methods in the operator now would belong in the hook.

Can you move the commented tests out of `core.py`? Maybe `airflow/contrib/tests`? We should probably make sure that the `./run_unit_tests.sh` command doesn't find and run those or the CI tests will fail.
Please squash into a set of meaningful commits if possible as you rebase.
Sorry about the delay, many of us took a nice break over the holidays and I wanted to stabilize a branch before letting a wave of stuff in. Reviewing now :)
:+1: looks solid, merging. Thanks for your patience :)
We had a plugin blow up on connection usage because it wasn't closing them properly and this new setting should help prevent connection number explosion even in the advent of misuse.

Super :-) I really appreciate this!  I hadn't expected that skipped upstream tasks affect downstream tasks (I presumed that they would be ignored in regards to triggered_by)

Not sure but is the TR.ONE_FAILED logic correct - it looks like it'll be set to skipped if anything succeeds - should it not be "if done >= upstream and not (failed or failed_upstream)"?

https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/823

I want to +1 this

`set_dag_runs_state` does limit dates to the range specified. It sets dag runs as running since clearing is typically used in order to re-run jobs. You can almost think of clear as a way to get the scheduler to re-run what you clear.

You either clear a failed state after you fix the issue and want it to re-run, or you clear a success state because it was a false positive or something has changed that requires re-running the task.

I'm not sure where to clarify that in the UI / CLI / docs. Let me know if you have input.
This looks cleaner to me. Thanks for the PR!
closes https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/827

I see, it doesn't look like there's an easy way to get that to play nicely with max_active_runs (ATM I'm stopping the scheduler, then "airflow clear", psql to delete dagrun, then start scheduler). Is there a reason why we those dag_runs to RUNNING rather than deleting them (won't the scheduler repopulate them anyway?)  They do disappear from the UI (tree view).

Each day reuses the same resources (directories etc), pooling and depends_on_past don't help - only max_active_runs does (tasks are roughly "delete directory", "product output into directory", "upload directory").  Maybe I need to use the external task sensor as per 768.
Good one! Thanks.

Welcome on board, Sidecar!
@bolkedebruin Sorry, I didn't tested the code under python3. Now I assure the code works under both python2 and 3.

This is not a bug, the DAGS_FOLDER gets replaced on the worker. The DAGS_FOLDER might be in a different location on different machines, so this is just a reference to where it may be.
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/airflow/bin/cli.py#L32
fixed - sorry, really should go and get pylint etc all hooked in properly

Thanks for the detailed report, this seem to be an edge case. That unique index is important as the pk of the task instances are dag_id/task_id/execution_date. If 2 dag runs had the same timestamp there would be collisions in the task_instance table. 

To me normally DAGs are either scheduled or externally triggered by nature, I'm not sure if I understand the hybrid use case and infer how to deal with collisions.

In python empty string evals as False, and empty strings are set as conf defaults.

`s.login` happens in an if block `if SMTP_USER and SMTP_PASSWORD`, so that line shouldn't execute if either are left empty.

From a technical perspective, I still believe there is an inconsistency between the DagRun migration scripts and the DagRun model which needs to be addressed / clarified. This index `dag_run.(dag_id, execution_date)` does not exist in the model but does exist in the migrations.

From a usability perspective, my DAG (referenced above) will not be scheduled without first manually externally triggering the initial run, even with my DAG flipped in the "ON" position. It is my desire to have my DAGs work on a schedule exclusively, but they would be scheduled only after the initial external trigger. Maybe the hybrid use case may not make sense, but it is a necessary starting point for this DAG.

I use `flake8` with the git commit hook
https://pypi.python.org/pypi/flake8

It will give warning only for the things you've touched which is nice. Other linters sometimes warn or alter more than what you bargain for.

Thanks for the PR!
Opened a PR (https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/835)

I think there's a bug there but I'm not sure that it's what you describe. 

The behavior we want is if SLA is 1 hour, we should error for the `2016-01-01` run at `2016-01-02T01:00:00` since the `2016-01-01` run can't start before `2016-01-02`.

One problem I see is that `following_schedule = dag.following_schedule(dttm)` should be in the while loop.
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/840
+1 this

I think that supporting both is confusing. Especially if an environment can be heterogenous in that regard on a per-dag or per-task (crazy!) basis. Also swapping from one way to another would offset (and mess up) the recorded state. 

I think it's easier to just align on this way of doing things. Left bound makes most sense to me.

Just think about that one statement in the docs being rewritten to take the optional approach: `Note that if you run a DAG on a schedule_interval of one day, ... BUT if you're not happy with that you can mess with the "date_achor_bound" (left|right) parameter in your airflow.cfg and get it to behave in a different way where the run for the 2015-01-01 rerpresents the run that should have started on that date where exectuion_date actually references 2014-12-31`. 

You'd read that and be like "damn. how is my environment set up? what's the default? should I change it? should I start an internal debate about this?"

Thanks for the feedback.  I admit I don't fully understand the internals of the scheduler.  But it doesn't necessarily need to a be a binary like `left|right`, though.  Couldn't the dag have a setting called `scheduler_wait` or something that is a `timedelta` that defaults to be equal to the `schedule_interval` but could be set to anything?  The scheduler would just do an extra time calculation to see whether it should trigger a `DagRun` for that dag.

@toryhaavik I think you can use the TimeDeltaSensor operator for this, although it doesn't currently seem to work with DAGs with no `schedule_interval` parameter. Also TimeSensor but I read somewhere that it will be deprecated in the future. See https://groups.google.com/forum/#!searchin/airbnb_airflow/timedeltasensor.

@mistercrunch Thanks for your feedback. I guess the difference in convention about 'gaps' in intervals causes the confusion for me. I interpret the execution dates of runs/tasks as 'points' in time where as you see it as 'intervals'.
Thank for the explanation. Then the ticket can be closed.
clear A with the "including downstream" option, then either let the scheduler pick up the tasks. You can do it from the UI or CLI.

Seems like this change could affect people by requiring new conf settings, is that what we want or should we just assume that everyone has all rights if those conf settings don't exist. 

I have no idea how many organizations are using this. Could be just you guys or could be 10...

Requiring new conf settings upon upgrade isn't a big deal though. I'm ok with that too.
Thanks for the PR!

I know that for clear we sometimes want either behavior, depending if you want to throw away the succeeded steps within the subdag or not. We used the CRUD "Task Instance" view when we just need to delete and not clear. 

For mark success I'm not sure why it's useful to mark the success within the sub dag. Do you have it set as `depends_on_past` within?
Relates to https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/848

Never encountered this issue. 
- airflow 1.6.2, 
- Debian Jessie (docker),
- Python 2.7.10
Confirms that it works when switching to Postgres. Seems to be specific to the SQLite database.

the start_date is a task level parameter. default_args is only a collection of defaults for the tasks within the DAG, you can override any of those by passing it into the operator's constructor.

Also note that only the active DAG runs should get processed and that if you were to want that backfill behavior you may have to re-activate DAG runs
